original_data.question:
A 65-year-old man presents with painless swelling of the neck over the past week. He also says he has been having intermittent fevers and severe night sweats which require a change of bed sheets the next day. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) diagnosed 10 years ago with which he admits to not always being compliant with his antiretroviral medication. The patient reports a 20-pack-year smoking history but no alcohol or recreational drug use. A review of systems is significant for a 6 kg (13.2 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. The vital signs include: temperature 37.8℃ (100.0℉) and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there are multiple non-tender swollen lymph nodes averaging 2 cm in diameter that is palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. Axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present on the right side. A cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The spleen size is 16 cm on percussion. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 88 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 130,000/mm3
    Serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Serum lactate dehydrogenase 1,000 U/L
An excisional biopsy of a superficial axillary lymph node on the right is performed and a histopathologic analysis confirms the most likely diagnosis. Which of the following is the next best diagnostic step in the workup of this patient?

model_response:
The patient has Burkitt lymphoma (BL) complicating his underlying HIV infection. The BL is a high grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) and is one of the AIDS-defining malignancies. It is more commonly seen in the oral cavity, jaw, and visceral organs. The TRAP test is used to help diagnose hairy cell leukemia (HCL). The other listed options are not associated with BL.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Cycles of fever with intervening periods of normothermia.
Perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
Equipment on which one may lie and sleep, especially as used to care for the hospital patient.

Devices used to cover the surface of a bed and/or operating and examination table. Sheets consist of broad rectangular pieces of fabric serving as basic articles of bedding and are made of woven (e.g. cotton and/or polyester, sateen) and nonwoven materials (e.g., tissue, paper). Some sheets are specifically made to fit adjustable beds and/or operating and examination tables and have wings and anchor straps designed to keep the sheets tucked in and tightly fitted. They are widely used in healthcare facilities, hospitals, nursing homes, medical offices, and at home. Dedicated sheets intended for examination and/or operating room tables and for patient beds are also available.
Occurring or done each day.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Human immunodeficiency virus. A non-taxonomic and historical term referring to any of two species, specifically HIV-1 and/or HIV-2. Prior to 1986, this was called human T-lymphotropic virus type III/lymphadenopathy-associated virus (HTLV-III/LAV). From 1986-1990, it was an official species called HIV. Since 1991, HIV was no longer considered an official species name; the two species were designated HIV-1 and HIV-2.

Human immunodeficiency virus. A non-taxonomic and historical term referring to any of two species, specifically HIV-1 and/or HIV-2. Prior to 1986, this was called human T-lymphotropic virus type III/lymphadenopathy-associated virus (HTLV-III/LAV). From 1986-1990, it was an official species called HIV. Since 1991, HIV was no longer considered an official species name; the two species were designated HIV-1 and HIV-2.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Agents used to treat RETROVIRIDAE INFECTIONS.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The history of when and what an individual smoke(s) or smoked.
The use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed.

Isotope bone densitometers that use a single source to yield an essentially monoenergetic (one discrete line spectrum) beam of gamma rays (x-ray photons). In addition to the single photon source, these densitometers typically include a scanner, a single-channel analyzer, and a computer with appropriate software. Single-photon densitometers are used to assess bone mineral content in the appendicular skeleton, usually by measuring the forearm (radius) or the heel.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
They are oval or bean shaped bodies (1 - 30 mm in diameter) located along the lymphatic system.
The length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle or sphere and connecting two points on the circumference.
Of or involving the front of a main body.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Area of the human body underneath the SHOULDER JOINT, also known as the armpit or underarm.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
Pertaining to both the heart and the lungs.
Enlargement of the spleen.
Act of striking a part with short, sharp blows as an aid in diagnosing the condition beneath the sound obtained.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of creatinine present in a sample of serum.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of lactate dehydrogenase present in a sample of serum.
A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.
Of little substance or significance; involving only a surface.
One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
